comments.body: Nit: we're using `Could not` but `Cannot` in other places... let's make it consistent (unless there's a reason to use past tense vs present tense)

ok, so what's about this rule:
> We use `cannot` if "it" (whatever IT is) can be never performed but `could not` if "it" cannot due to some exceptional circumstances.

Hence:
- `Cannot create file 'machete': Directory with the same name exists` b/c it is never possible while the directory exists
- `Could not open Git Machete tab` b/c we are not able to specify why it was not opened; it could be missing tool window or missing content(tab) but we neither want to expose the technical terms nor we know the actual reason why the tool window or the content tab is null; most likely it's disabled Git Vcs
Ok! Pls apply & document in .properties file or in CONTRIBUTING.md

comments.body: @mkondratek @micpiotrowski will it be still correct if we just forbid single `'` in the strings completely? :thinking:
With single `'` only this is evaluated to no `'` at all (IIUC your question).

Ok but can we ban the regex `[^']'[^']` completely in this file?

It'd be nice to answer the following questions:

1. is there any context where `''` (double single quote) will NOT render as `'`?
2. is there any context where `'` (single single quote) will  NOT render as `'`?

I suspect the 1=>NO && 2=>YES... so forbidding single single quote would be a good idea then :thinking:

Also the comment `WE use single quotes for indication` in line 2 is slightly misleading, maybe:

```
# Action descriptions & texts - no formatting allowed (for indication we use double single quotes, which are rendered as single single quotes)
```

The followed rule of thumb provided by @PawelLipski via Slack conversation should be fine:
* strings that have any `{N}` must NOT have `'`, but `''` instead
* strings that do NOT have any `{N}` are NOT meant to be passed through MessageFormat and hence must NOT have `''` but plain `'` instead

These are detailed rules about `'` in `MessageFormat`:
```
Within a String, a pair of single quotes can be used to quote any arbitrary characters except single quotes. For example, pattern string "'{0}'" represents string "{0}", not a FormatElement. A single quote itself must be represented by doubled single quotes '' throughout a String. For example, pattern string "'{''}'" is interpreted as a sequence of '{ (start of quoting and a left curly brace), '' (a single quote), and }' (a right curly brace and end of quoting), not '{' and '}' (quoted left and right curly braces): representing string "{'}", not "{}".

A SubformatPattern is interpreted by its corresponding subformat, and subformat-dependent pattern rules apply. For example, pattern string "{1,number,$'#',##}" (SubformatPattern with underline) will produce a number format with the pound-sign quoted, with a result such as: "$#31,45". Refer to each Format subclass documentation for details.

Any unmatched quote is treated as closed at the end of the given pattern. For example, pattern string "'{0}" is treated as pattern "'{0}'".

Any curly braces within an unquoted pattern must be balanced. For example, "ab {0} de" and "ab '}' de" are valid patterns, but "ab {0'}' de", "ab } de" and "''{''" are not.
```
Source: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/text/MessageFormat.html
Ok, pls provide a script to enforce the two above rules

comments.body: Hmm why single single quote here but double single quote in other cases? :thinking:

The pair of single-quotes escape format placeholders (like `{0}`). Additionally, double single quote reduces to a single single-quote. Single signle-quote is just a single single-quote. :rofl: 

Eventually, it looks correctly (see the image above).

Aaaah okay, so the only potential error would be to first declare prop as `hello '{0}'` (and not `hello ''{0}''`) and then try to pass argument to this escaped `'{0}'`, right? This should be anyway captured by `I18nFormatChecker` (you can verify at your convenience btw)
verified
